title: How to Paint Pottery

steps.headline: First make sure you know what cone your bisque ware has been fired to.
steps.description: Choose a glaze that is made for that cone level!

steps.headline: Select a soft paintbrush.
steps.description: Some people prefer large, flat Chinese wash brushes. Make sure the brush is clean!

steps.headline: Rinse your bisque ware quickly under cold water to remove dust and other impurities that may cause glaze defects.
steps.description: Do not dry it, it will dry on its own fairly quickly. Besides, a little dampness will help the glaze go on more smoothly.

steps.headline: If you have a banding wheel, use it!
Stir your glaze thoroughly with a clean fork.
steps.description: Then make sure the lid is on tightly and shake it up.

steps.headline: Glaze the inside first.
steps.description: Pour some glaze into the bowl or pot and swirl it around so that it covers the entire inside, then pour it back into the bottle. If the inside has holes or the shape is not conducive to this method, then paint 3 coats on the inside. If you are pouring it in, you only need ONE COAT. Do not bother painting the rim yet....

steps.headline: Turn the pot upside down on the banding wheel and paint 3 coats over the outside.
steps.description: Try not to get any glaze on the bottom of the pot. If it is high fire clay and glaze (cone 3 or higher), then leave at least 1/4" before the bottom of the pot unglazed. Some people use wax.

steps.headline: After the glaze is dry enough to handle, then turn it right side up and paint the rim with 2-3 coats and touch up any missed areas.
Let the pot dry and wipe off the bottom with a damp sponge prior to firing.
Fire it to the correct cone.
I usually have an assembly line of pots that I glaze this way, except that I layer multiple colors for interesting effects.
Experiment and make test tiles for more predictable results.
Keep a notebook so that you can remember combinations of glazes that works and doesn't work.
Under glazes are fun to use to if you like to paint a lot of detail.
steps.description: You just paint enough to cover and fire them on, then clear glaze them with 2-3 coats of transparent glaze and fire them again.

steps.headline: Have fun, I personally love glazing by brushing, to me it is more exciting and personal that dipping in large vats of glaze.
steps.description: Just make sure you have about 3 coats of glaze for the best results. Too little and the results will be streaky and not shiny, too much and it will run and drip and ruin your pots and shelves.

text: First make sure you know what cone your bisque ware has been fired to. Choose a glaze that is made for that cone level! Select a soft paintbrush. Some people prefer large, flat Chinese wash brushes. Make sure the brush is clean! Rinse your bisque ware quickly under cold water to remove dust and other impurities that may cause glaze defects. Do not dry it, it will dry on its own fairly quickly. Besides, a little dampness will help the glaze go on more smoothly. If you have a banding wheel, use it!  Stir your glaze thoroughly with a clean fork. Then make sure the lid is on tightly and shake it up. Glaze the inside first. Pour some glaze into the bowl or pot and swirl it around so that it covers the entire inside, then pour it back into the bottle. If the inside has holes or the shape is not conducive to this method, then paint 3 coats on the inside. If you are pouring it in, you only need ONE COAT. Do not bother painting the rim yet.... Turn the pot upside down on the banding wheel and paint 3 coats over the outside. Try not to get any glaze on the bottom of the pot. If it is high fire clay and glaze (cone 3 or higher), then leave at least 1/4" before the bottom of the pot unglazed. Some people use wax. After the glaze is dry enough to handle, then turn it right side up and paint the rim with 2-3 coats and touch up any missed areas.  Let the pot dry and wipe off the bottom with a damp sponge prior to firing.  Fire it to the correct cone.  I usually have an assembly line of pots that I glaze this way, except that I layer multiple colors for interesting effects.  Experiment and make test tiles for more predictable results.  Keep a notebook so that you can remember combinations of glazes that works and doesn't work.  Always use lead-free glazes. Read the labels! Under glazes are fun to use to if you like to paint a lot of detail. You just paint enough to cover and fire them on, then clear glaze them with 2-3 coats of transparent glaze and fire them again. Have fun, I personally love glazing by brushing, to me it is more exciting and personal that dipping in large vats of glaze. Just make sure you have about 3 coats of glaze for the best results. Too little and the results will be streaky and not shiny, too much and it will run and drip and ruin your pots and shelves.
